title: HTML is sometimes called a programming language but it has no logic, so is a
markup language
b
. HTML tags provide semantic meaning and machine-readability to the content in the page.

title: Tag | Meaning — | —
<!DOCTYPE>
c
| Defines the HTML version used in the document. In this case it is HTML5.See the
doctypes topic
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/html/806/doctypes
for more information.
<html>
c
| Opens the page. No markup should come after the closing tag (
</html>
c
). The
lang
c
attribute declares the primary language of the page using the
ISO language codes
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_ISO_639-1_codes
en
c
for English).See the
Content Language topic
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/html/737/content-languages#t=201607221637059314928
for more information.
<head>
c
| Opens the head section, which does not appear in the main browser window but mainly contains information
about
i
the HTML document, called
metadata
i
. It can also contain imports from external stylesheets and scripts. The closing tag is
</head>
c
<meta>
c
| Gives the browser some metadata about the document. The
charset
c
attribute declares the
character encoding
a
https://www.w3.org/International/questions/qa-html-encoding-declarations.en
. Modern HTML documents should always use
UTF-8
a
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UTF-8
, even though it is not a requirement. In HTML, the
<meta>
c
tag does not require a closing tag.See the
Meta topic
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/html/1264/meta
for more information.
<title>
c
| The title of the page. Text written between this opening and the closing tag (
</title>
c
) will be displayed on the tab of the page or in the title bar of the browser.
<body>
c
| Opens the part of the document displayed to users, i.e. all the visible or audible content of a page. No content should be added after the closing tag
</body>
c
<h1>
c
| A level 1 heading for the page.See
headings
a
http://stackoverflow.com/documentation/html/226/headings
for more information.
c
| Represents a common paragraph of text.
